insight_content: Use “dumb” checklists for “smart” days On good brain days, I used to forget basic stuff like brushing my

source_title: 10 simple organization hacks that actually work for my ADHD brain
insight_content: them. But putting my meds next to the kettle? That works. We ADHD brains are object permanence-challenged. If we don’t see it, it doesn’t exist. Try this: Move your most forgotten task into your line of sight. Put it in your walking path. Tape it to your laptop if you have to. 5. Pick your “launch pad” This one saved me from the daily panic of missing essentials. I now have a “launch pad” by the front door: keys, wallet, work bag, meds, umbrella. It’s all there, waiting like a faithful golden retriever. Try this: Create a launch pad. Use a basket, shelf, or even a shoebox. Put your everyday essentials there. Non-negotiable. 6. Name your bins like a weirdo I used to shove things in random boxes. Out of sight, out of mind…until I needed them. Now, I give bins funny, obvious names. One says “Cables & Crap.” Another is “Stuff I Pretend I’ll Return.” It makes me smile —

source_title: 🧠 Flipping the script on “hating your ADHD”

source_title: 🧠 Flipping the script on “hating your ADHD”
insight_content: with too many graphs. It was when I watched a friend (who also had ADHD) absolutely crush a creative project in 48 hours flat. No plan. No checklist. No structure. Just pure focus. Obsession. Flow. And I remember thinking... Wait a sec. Why does she get to be a genius with ADHD, and I get to be a failure? That’s when the switch flipped. Maybe ADHD isn’t the villain. Maybe it’s the script that’s broken... not the character. The “hating your ADHD” script goes like this: You get distracted → You beat yourself up You hyperfocus for 12 hours → You call yourself “crazy” You miss a deadline → You label yourself “lazy” You interrupt someone → You call yourself “rude” You get addicted to something (or someone) → You call yourself “damaged” And this whole time, you’re dragging around this emotional backpack full of shame, telling yourself you need to “do better” and “just be normal.” But guess what? Normal doesn’t exist. And ADHD doesn’t need fixing. It needs reframing. So I flipped the script... I stopped looking at my ADHD like a diagnosis... and started treating it like a language I was never taught to read. A neurodivergent dialect. With its own grammar. Tempo. Rhythm. Needs. Here’s what changed when I stopped hating it: 🧨 Impulsivity became courage I used to make risky choices and then shame myself for days. Now? I know my gut works fast... sometimes faster than my fear. That same impulsivity helped me leave toxic jobs, start a business, say yes to scary things. I don’t shame it anymore. I train it. 🔁 Repetition became pattern-recognition All those times I’d “make the same mistake again and again”? Now I see those loops as data. Addiction, for me, was just an attempt to self-regulate in a world that wasn’t built for my nervous system. It wasn’t a moral failing. It was a cry for balance. 🧃 Dopamine-chasing became flow-hacking I learned I’m not addicted to chaos. I’m addicted to novelty . So I stopped trying to force myself to work like neurotypicals... and I started building around my dopamine needs. Timers. Body doubling. Creative sprints. Micro-rewards. I made my own rulebook. 🚀 And that scattered energy? Became my superpower Some people focus on one thing for 10 years. I can master something in 2 weeks when I’m locked in. That’s not a deficit. That’s a f*cking gift. But only when I stopped trying to suppress it. Real talk: You can’t hate yourself into healing I tried.

source_title: The Moment It Clicked: My Late Diagnosis Story
insight_content: use there was zero dopamine in Ovid’s love poems or Cicero’s letters. The causes and consequences of the

source_title: The Moment It Clicked: My Late Diagnosis Story
insight_content: make things easier — it just meant the stakes were higher. At work, I constantly misread social signs and

source_title: The Moment It Clicked: My Late Diagnosis Story
insight_content: social signs and was hopeless at office politics. The same thing happened when I became an Anglican priest. I loved parts of the role, but apart from Sunday I lacked a daily structure and was often blind to unspoken rules just like previous jobs, that others seemed to navigate effortlessly. Alcohol became my shortcut to confidence. It dulled the exhaustion and smoothed over the gaps in my social game. But the cost was high. Eventually, my marriage fell apart. And so did I. The unexpected connection at an AA meeting Then, one day in an AA meeting, everything shifted. A woman began to share her story. In detail, her life looked nothing like mine. But as she described her struggles at work and the way she’d always felt different, it was like listening to my own thoughts being spoken aloud. In that moment, the penny dropped. A personal epiphany. That’s my story exactly — apart from getting pregnant, of course. I sat there thinking: Oh my God. This is it. This is me. My wife’s push and the official diagnosis Even then, I didn’t rush to act. It was my wife who gently pushed me: “Maybe you should get tested.” At 54 years old, I finally did. When the diagnosis came back — autistic, with ADHD — I felt a rush of emotions collide: relief that I finally had an explanation, sadness for the years I’d spent stumbling in the dark, and a quiet strength knowing I wasn’t imagining it. If I’m honest, I knew before the results came in. The moment I suspected, I went into hyperfocus mode, researching everything I could get my hands on. The “aha” moment: self-doubt turning into self-acceptance That was the moment it clicked.
